case_vignette: A 22-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with itchy eyes. The patient recently moved to the northern US and states that he has experienced bilateral itching and watering of his eyes. He states that it is very distracting and is making it hard for him to work. The patient denies any recent sick contacts and lives alone. He works as a machinist and is currently struggling with his finances. The patient has a past medical history of asthma, and his current medications include albuterol, fluticasone, fish oil, and whey protein supplements. His temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 100/65 mmHg, pulse is 60/min, respirations are 15/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Cardiopulmonary exam is within normal limits. You notice the bilateral findings seen in Figure A. Otoscopy reveals bilateral clear tympanic membranes. The rest of the patient's physical exam is within normal limits.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
My eyes are itchy and watering a lot, and it's really distracting me from my work.
Is this condition chronic or recent onset?
This started recently after I moved to the northern US.
Have you been exposed to any allergens in your new environment?
I am not sure; I haven't noticed any specific allergens.
Is there any history of allergies or asthma in your family?
I have a history of asthma myself.

Final Diagnosis: Allergic Conjunctivitis or Seasonal Allergies.

Please consult with an ophthalmologist or allergist for proper diagnosis and treatment.
